fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
For the S3 Artifact Handler configuration, we need to provide the AWS key and secret key. These are long-lived access keys which are not allowed by some companies' security policies.

h3. Suggested Solution
Have options of Access Key or IAM profile for S3 authentication.

h3. Why this is important
Some security policies prohibit the use of long-lived access keys like AWS keys
fields.summary: Use IAM profile to authenticate to S3 for artifact handlers

fields.description:
h6.Problem Description:
Currently, the DeletionServiceImpl Service is run every 24hr or at every restart of the Bamboo Application. If we have a configurable parameter for this service then it would be very convenient and useful for the customers.

h6.Suggested Solution:
* Have a configurable parameter which a user can configure from the bamboo UI

h6.Workaround:
No Workaround except restarting the Bamboo.
fields.summary: Make the DeletionServiceImpl service as configurable
Bamboo doesn't delete data from "deployment_env_vcs_location" table when deleting marked for deleted data from table "vcs_location"

fields.description:
Currently I have to add each of our Bitbucket repository as linked repository in Bamboo individually with the same settings, which for a microservice architecture is quite a lot of work to set up and maintain.

Instead, I would like to link the Bitbucket project instead and all repositories get automatically listed as linked repositories.
fields.summary: Linked Projects in Bamboo instead of only repositories

fields.description:
When you clone job from one plan to another Bamboo will detect that job has artifact subscriptions and fail. It is by design, because new job would not have access to artifacts from source plan.

However:
 * there is no error message what went wrong making it very confusing for user (there is also no error in Bamboo logs)
 * after error occurs, list of jobs is never refreshed and always points to a current plan, no matter what is selected in source plan list
 * at first list of jobs is not sorted, after an error it's sorted alphabetically (it should be always sorted)
fields.summary: Cloning Job from one plan to another fails silently when it has artifact subscriptions

fields.description:
h6.Problem Description:
Currently, we do not have REST API Call to delete projects/plans in Bamboo. This could be very useful in managing multiple plans remotely to increase the efficiency and productivity when dealing with lots of projects/plans cleanup.

h6.Suggested Solution:
Open a REST API call to delete Projects/Plans

h6.Workaround:
Manually delete the plans/projects from the Bamboo UI.
fields.summary: REST API to delete Deployment projects & Plans

fields.description:
h6.Problem Description:
Agent Home "/tmp/log_spool" directory is not cleaned by Bamboo thus resulting in huge space consumption of space on the disk.

h6.Suggested Solution:
We should have some sort of functionality to remove the files from this directory to maintain the space on the disk.

h6.Workaround:
* Manually delete the files from this directory.
or
* Create a script to schedule the cleanup.

h6. Note
The fix for this only applies to Linux agents. It is fixed in 7.0 for Windows agents too: [BAM\-21084: log_spool folder is not cleaned on Windows remote agents (fixed in Bamboo 7.0.1)|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-21084]
fields.summary: Agent Home "/tmp/log_spool" directory is not cleaned by Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
h3. Whenever new changes are pushed, Bamboo scans the repository and typically update specs plan. In that plan, the build starts with checking out a repository in which it's defined. However, when we run a customised build and the repository is checked out at a specific revision, Bamboo does not update specs plan with the current contents of that respective revision, instead the last "saved state" is parsed and executed. That means, for any custom revision, the specs from the last "Specs configuration update" build is used.

Steps to reproduce:
 # Push new changes followed by another to YAML specs repository. This creates 2 new builds with 2 "Specs configuration updated"
 # Now, hit "Run -> Run customised..." and give Revision number of the first revision.
 # The custom build will be executed, however, the Specs configuration update will still use the latest one. 

h3. Suggested Solution

When a customized build is run with a custom revision (using *Run customised... option*), Bamboo should use the specs from exactly that revision, as the YAML specs definition content might differ.

In other words, when we run a customized build and the repository is checked out at a specific revision, the expected behavior should be that if there is a specs file, it's current contents (from that revision) should be parsed and executed, and not the last "saved state".
h3. Workaround (Optional) 

There is no workaround for now.
fields.summary: Bamboo YAML Specs should be evaluated prior to the build
Add agent info to build result REST API

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, the only way to access the logs on an elastic agent is an SCP task, or to SSH into the elastic agent.  These both depend on the agent instance to still be 'alive'.

From a support perspective we would like to retrieve the agent logs to determine why a build or deploy failed, but if the instance is already decommissioned, those logs are no longer available.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add an option to the Elastic Agent configuration to sync elastic agent logs to an S3 bucket,  so they can be retrieved later.
 
h3. Workaround

A script can be added to the elastic agent customization to create a cron job which will use the amazon CLI to copy files to S3 on a schedule.  This is not always very intuitive.

{noformat}
echo "*/15 * * * * aws s3 sync /home/bamboo/bamboo-elastic-agent.out <bucketURI>" >> /etc/crontab
{noformat}
fields.summary: Sync Elastic Agent Logs to an S3 Bucket
Test - IGNORE

fields.summary: The bundled Atlassian Application Links plugin had various XSS issues - CVE-2018-5227

fields.description:
A remote agent gets registered in Bamboo by IP address / hostname. If network changes from IPv4 to IPv6, a new agent will be created, having \(x) appended to its name. This can create a great amount of work for users when Dedication was applied. Since a new agent got registered, dedication will no longer work and unintentional builds could be triggered in agents.

With that said, Bamboo could have an option to prevent this from happening.

Also, it could have an option to specify agents name in start-up command:
{noformat}
-Dbamboo-agent-name=My Remote Agent
{noformat}

This would also allow users to run the same Remote Agent on different environments without having the necessity of migrating <bamboo-remote-home> directory.

In case Remote Agent is already online, prevent agent from starting up.
fields.summary: Allow Remote Agent to impersonate

fields.description:
It would very interesting having the ability to start up Bamboo Remote Agents and prevent them from being available until configuration is complete.

As a example:
* Company A outsources Bamboo to Company B and Company C
* Company B and Company C coincidentally have the same environment where remote agent can be run
* Company B already have remote agents up and running with Company A
* Company C issue a remote agent to Company A

What could happen:
* Builds from Company B could end up being executed in Company C before Requirement or Dedication is set
fields.summary: Allow Remote Agent to be started in disabled mode
Build monitoring page message descriptions

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently Bamboo does not support Gerrit by default
h3. Suggested Solution
Add support for Gerrit as a repository
h4. Why this is important 
Bamboo admins have to install a Gerrit plugin which currently only supports up to an old version of Bamboo
fields.summary: Add support for Gerrit in Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Scenario
* Maintenance scheduled for 8:00 PM
* Current time, 7:44 PM
* Estimate time for PROJ-PLAN for completion 20min based on previous builds

h3. Expected result
Based on information presented, Bamboo should not assign Job to agent since it will delay maintenance window, leaving build in queue for when resuming Bamboo

h3. Actual result
Bamboo assign Job to agent, delaying maintenance window
fields.summary: Builds should not interfere with maintenance window

fields.description:
Bamboo has two endpoint to place Bamboo in maintenance mode:
# http://myhost.com:8085/rest/api/latest/server/pause \[[POST|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/REST/6.3.1/#d2e2948]]
#* While running PAUSE, Bamboo will wait for builds to complete (_InProgress state_) before placing Bamboo into PAUSED state
#* Builds are prevented from being queued
#* Bamboo can be resumed http://myhost.com:8085/rest/api/latest/server/resume \[[POST|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/REST/6.3.1/#d2e2962]]
# http://myhost.com:8085/rest/api/latest/server/prepareForRestart \[[PUT|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/REST/6.3.1/#d2e2955]]
#* Prepare server for restarting: suspend change detection, stop indexing, stop ec2 instance ordering
#* Builds that were {color:blue}Queued{color} will change status to {color:blue}NotBuilt{color} upon Bamboo's restart
#* Builds that were {color:blue}InProgress{color} will change status to {color:blue}NotBuilt{color} upon Bamboo's restart
#* Builds are prevented from being queued
#* Bamboo must be restarted, it cannot be resumed

Regardless the chosen endpoint, Bamboo should allow builds to continue on being queue instead of allowing it only after resume or restart.
fields.summary: Allow builds to be queued during Bamboo's maintenance

fields.description:
Please standardize examples from the *Troubleshooting* section inside the [Securing Bamboo with Tomcat using SSL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/securing-bamboo-with-tomcat-using-ssl-391087422.html] documentation.

For instance, under *Wrong certificate*, we use the following connector example:

{noformat}
<Connector port="8443" 
	maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"
	maxThreads="150" 
  	minSpareThreads="25" 
  	maxSpareThreads="75"
	enableLookups="false" 
  	disableUploadTimeout="true" 
  	useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
	acceptCount="100" 
  	scheme="https" 
  	secure="true"
	clientAuth="false" 
  	sslProtocol="TLS"
	keystoreFile="/opt/local/.keystore"
	keystorePass="removed"
	keyAlias="tomcat"
/> 
{noformat}

However, scrolling down the page a little bit we have another example of connector under *Use the Http11Protocol to handle SSL connections*:

{noformat}
 <Connector port="8443" 
	protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Protocol"
	maxHttpHeaderSize="8192" 
	SSLEnabled="true" 
	keystoreFile="${user.home}/.keystore"
	maxThreads="150" 
	enableLookups="false" 
	disableUploadTimeout="true"
	acceptCount="100" 
	scheme="https" 
	secure="true"
	clientAuth="false" 
	sslProtocol="TLS" 
	useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
/>
{noformat}

In the first example here we show all the {{keystore}} parameters: keystoreFile, keystorePass and keyAlias. On the other hand, in the second example it appears uses must use only one of them: keystoreFile.

This causes confusion as most of the users attempt to follow exactly what is written in the documentation, and sometimes they even copy&paste the example. The connector from the second example will fail if, for example, the keystorePass is different from the default and the user does not specify it, since in our own example we don't specify it.

My suggestion is to use all the three {{keystore}} parameters in the second example as well, since the only actual change between the first example here and the second one is the type of protocol we're using to troubleshoot the problem: *org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Protocol*.
fields.summary: Standardize examples from the Troubleshooting section inside the Securing Bamboo with Tomcat using SSL documentation

fields.description:
When build plan is managed by Bamboo Specs in repository it's readonly at UI so user can't modify it and have to use source code to make a change.

Deployment project should also follow same scenario but it doesn't which makes possible situation when deployment project configuration will be overwritten by Bamboo Specs
fields.summary: Deployment project should be readonly when managed by Bamboo Specs in repository

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If would be nice to have a system notification to notify users in the event of a new remote agent pending approval. Currently Bamboo does not provide any sort of remote agent notification event, such as when an agent becomes online/offline. There's a 3rd party plugin that provides such feature called [Bamboo Agent Notifications|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassianlab.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-agent-notification-plugin/server/overview], but not even the plugin provides the ability to trigger notifications when a new remote agent request comes in. The plugin only notifies users in case an _existing_ remote agent goes online/offline.

It would be very useful to have some sort of notification for agents that require manual approval when remote agent authentication is turned on.
fields.summary: Remote agent manual approval notification

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Tasks that require executables should only display the ones that are available to the agent capable of building that job whether by agent dedication or by agents whose capabilities meet the job requirements.

Currently Bamboo displays a list of *all* available capabilities across all agents when setting up a task, the problem here is that the job might've been dedicated to a specific agent already, so Bamboo should really only display the capabilities available in the agent and not those from completely unrelated agents. 

Said differently, agent dedication may prevent your jobs from running on my agent, but it doesn't prevent your agent's capabilities from unduly influencing my projects/plans/jobs.
fields.summary: Tasks should only display executables from agents that are capable of building the job

fields.description: If user doesn't have view permission to running or queued build it will be not shown in Build activity page. It should show estimated time duration for build finishing to help user predict queue time of their builds
fields.summary: Show estimated build duration for build without view permission

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Most of the times plans are using local repositories and therefore it's not possible to use them inside deployment environments without turning them into Linked repositories. Bamboo does not allow users to make use of plan-level repositories as part of the deployment environment configuration even though the entire deployment project is configured to use a single build plan as the source of information.

It would be nice if users could choose from repositories that were created in the source build plan inside the _Source Code Checkout_ task from a deployment environment.
fields.summary: Provide ability to use plan-level repositories inside deployment environments

h3. Problem Definition
We can't configure the stage and job names in specs. They are important to keep the build configuration organized and help on troubleshooting

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow the name property to be available for both job and stage. Jobs could even have the JOB-KEY configurable
fields.summary: Allow stage name and job name to be configured in YAML specs

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo gets extremely slow after updating a task on a plan with multiple branches (e.g. hundreds or even thousands of branches). The more branches you add to your plan, the more time it takes to load pages that need to access plan cache information, because Bamboo invalidates the plan cache when editing a task.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two plans inside Bamboo.
# Create a Script task inside the job from each plan with a simple *echo*.
{noformat}
echo "Hello world!"
{noformat}
# Create a few plan branches inside the first plan.
# Create ~1000 plan branches inside the second plan.
# Open two different tabs in your browser and access the job configuration page for both plans.
#* Inside the second plan open up the Script task and save it -- it's not even necessary to perform changes, just save the task.
#* After that click something else, try to access another task if you have one or click the Job details or even Requirements tab.
# Now back to the tab with the first plan open, click around as well (e.g. Job details tab, Requirements tab, Artifacts tab, and etc).
# Open a third tab and access the Bamboo *Build Dashboard* page.

h3. Expected Results
* You are able to navigate and access all the information across all tabs with no problems and more importantly, with no delays.

h3. Actual Results
* Inside the tab with the first plan open you can actually navigate with no problems. It's a rather small plan with only a handful of branches. Furthermore since you're inside the plan, it is not necessary to load/access the cache from other plans.
* For the tab with the second plan nothing happens, Bamboo just hangs and waits until it finishes updating the task you saved and rebuild the plan cache. Inside a plan with ~1000 plan branches this can take up to 5 minutes of waiting.
* All other pages that attempt to access that plan cache information (e.g. Build Dashboard, Build activity, and etc) will also hang and it turn all other users have to wait until Bamboo is done updating the cache information because one user updated a task. This is a *huge* problem because one user, editing a single task, can halt Bamboo and prevent other users from accessing the application.
** None of the administrative pages are affected because we're not accessing plan cache information there, so one would not even notice the problem while going through the Agents page, Server capabilities or even the Users and Groups page. None of the admin pages demonstrate slowness.

h3.Workaround
* Reduce the number of plan branches across all your plans to less than 100 plan branches or even less than that, if possible.
* Use Specs to update the plan configuration as opposed to the UI. Split the plan into many plans, each having only a subset of (somehow logically-divided) plan branches. This way Specs would become beneficial and a good replacement for the UI in a few ways:
** Even without limiting number of plan branches, updating of tasks will happen in the background, so users won't have to wait for each operation to finish to proceed.
** It will make it easier to limit number of plan branches, because it will be easier to create multiple plans sharing similar logic (same code in Specs, just different key and name for each plan, mainly to ensure consistency), and each one of the plans could have just a small number of plan branches, not all of them at once.
fields.summary: Bamboo extremely slow after updating a task on a plan with multiple branches

fields.description:
h3. Summary
{color:blue}Trigger dependencies only when all stages have been run successfully{color} is not being selected when requireAllStagesPassing(true) method gets called.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo v6.3.1, 6.3.2

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Implement method described in https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/6.3.1/specs-java.html#dependencies
{noformat}
Plan plan = new Plan(project, "My Plan One", "PLAN1")
    .description("This is an example of a plan")
    .enabled(true)
    .stages(stage1)
    .dependencies(new Dependencies()
        .configuration(new DependenciesConfiguration()
            .requireAllStagesPassing(true))
        .childPlans(new PlanIdentifier("PROA", "PLAN2"), new PlanIdentifier("PROA", "PLAN3")));
{noformat}


h3. Expected Results
Checkbox {color:blue}Trigger dependencies only when all stages have been run successfully{color} in {color:blue}Plan configuration >> Dependencies{color} should be checked.

h3. Actual Results
Checkbox {color:blue}Trigger dependencies only when all stages have been run successfully{color} is unchecked

h3. Workaround
Make use of {color:blue}pluginConfigurations{color} until this issue gets fixed:
{noformat}
.dependencies(new Dependencies().childPlans(new PlanIdentifier(projectKey, planKey)))
                .pluginConfigurations(new AllOtherPluginsConfiguration()
                        .configuration(new MapBuilder()
                            .put("custom.dependencies.triggerOnlyAfterAllStages", "true")
                            .build()));
{noformat}
{color:blue}custom.dependencies.triggerOnlyAfterAllStages{color} relates to option {color:blue}Trigger dependencies only when all stages have been run successfully{color} under {color:blue}Plan configuration >> Dependencies{color} tab (Reference: https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/6.3.2/specs-java.html#dependencies)
fields.summary: Bamboo Specs requireAllStagesPassing(true) does not update plan

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The Bitbucket cloud repository type should support Bitbucket smart mirroring: 
* [Smart Mirroring for Bitbucket Cloud|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/smart-mirroring-for-bitbucket-cloud-838427434.html]
* [Work with Bitbucket Smart Mirroring \- Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/work-with-bitbucket-smart-mirroring-838427532.html]

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow users to select which mirror they want to use to get their repository data from.
 
h3. Workaround
Use the git repository type pointing directly to Bitbucket cloud.
(!) This workaround will not solve the problem completely. The Bitbucket cloud integration features will be lost (Pull request plan branch management, build statuses on Bitbucket cloud side, etc)
fields.summary: Add Bitbucket mirror support to Bitbucket cloud repository type

fields.description:
h2. Summary

The Global Permissions screen is not displaying a user group that has been added after reboot. The group retains permissions and access, but the group is not displayed. Believed to be caused by group name formatting ( ie. special characters, capitalization).

Entry from the ACL_ENTRY table displaying that the group is known to Bamboo:
{code:java}
ID ACL_OBJECT_IDENTITY TYPE SID ACE_ORDER MASK GRANTING AUDIT_SUCCESS AUDIT_FAILURE53444609 65537 GROUP_PRINCIPAL TEST-Bamboo-Group 0 16 1 0 0{code}
 

This seems similar to [BAM-12325| https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-12325], but it has been fixed so I am opening this new bug.

h2. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add user group to Bamboo via the Global Permissions page.
# Restart Bamboo
# View Global Permissions Page

h2. Expected outcome
It's expected that the group will retain their permissions and be displayed in the Global Permissions page.

h2. Actual Outcome
Group retains permissions but is not displayed in the Global Permissions page.

h2. Environment Details
* Bamboo 6.3.0
* LDAP
fields.summary: Global Permissions Page blank

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo is showing incorrect metadata when a build is re-run.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make sure you have at least 2 users inside Bamboo (e.g. admin and bob).
# Create a new Plan.
#* It's not even necessary to set up a source repository.
# Create 2 stages inside the plan and make the second one is a manual stage:
#* Default Stage.
#* Second Stage.
# Inside the first stage create a job with a simple script task (e.g. echo "My first job!").
# Inside the second stage create another job with a simple script task (e.g. echo "My second job!").
# As the *admin* user, trigger the first build of that plan, including the manual stage.
# Log out of Bamboo and log back in as *bob*.
# Access that build and click *Run > Rerun this build*, including the manual stage.
# After that check the {{Metadata}} tab for both the build result and the second job result.

h3. Expected Results

Both jobs should display the following metadata:

h6. Job #1

||Key||Value||
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.stageName|Default Stage|
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName|bob|

h6. Job #2

||Key||Value||
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.stageName|Second Stage|
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName|bob|

This is because bob re-run the build.

h3. Actual Results

The build metadata information is correct but the jobs are not:

h6. Job #1

||Key||Value||
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.stageName|Second Stage|
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName|admin|

h6. Job #2

||Key||Value||
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.stageName|Default Stage|
|ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName|admin|

Each job is displaying the incorrect stage name -- it should be the other way around -- and both jobs have the user name set to admin when in fact bob is the one that re-run that build.
fields.summary: Incorrect job result metadata after build re-run

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo reports some groups coming from Microsoft Active Directory with 0 user count when in fact they have a considerable amount of users (members).

!viewGroups.png|thumbnail!

In this case both *BAMBOO* groups are coming from Microsoft Active Directory. The first one (BAMBOO-ENGR) has 15 users, but the second one (BAMBOO-USERS) has +1.500 users. The second group is showing up with 0 users inside Bamboo.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo connect to Microsoft Active Directory.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect Bamboo to Microsoft Active Directory using the following document: [Integrating Bamboo with LDAP|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/integrating-bamboo-with-ldap-289277210.html].
# Create two groups inside AD:
#* BAMBOO-USERS
Add more than 1.500 users to this group.
#* BAMBOO-ENGR
Add just a few users to this group (e.g. 15 users).
# To ensure that you're only loading users from those two groups we just created and that you're also just synchronizing those groups, configure Bamboo to:
#* look for those groups inside your AD tree:
{noformat}
<groupSearchFilter>(&(objectCategory=group)(|(cn=BAMBOO-ENGR)(cn=BAMBOO-USERS)))</groupSearchFilter>
{noformat}
#* filter users that only belong to those groups:
{noformat}
<userSearchFilter>(&(objectCategory=Person)(sAMAccountName=*)(|(memberOf=CN=BAMBOO-ENGR,OU=bamboo,DC=atlassian,DC=local)(memberOf=CN=BAMBOO-USERS,OU=bamboo,DC=atlassian,DC=local)))</userSearchFilter>
{noformat}
#* use member as the membership attribute:
{noformat}
<membershipAttribute>member</membershipAttribute>
{noformat}
# Once everything has been configured correctly access the following pages inside Bamboo:
#* Bamboo administration > Overview > Security > Users
#* Bamboo administration > Overview > Security > Groups

h3. Expected Results

The first page, the *Users* page, will give you a list of all users and groups they belong to -- either BAMBOO-ENGR, BAMBOO-USERS or both. The second page, the *Groups* page, should report the correct number of users belonging to those two groups we created (e.g. BAMBOO-USERS with over 1.500 users and BAMBOO-ENGR with 15 users).

h3. Actual Results

The first page will give you all correct results but the *Groups* page on the other hand will display the user count as 0 for the BAMBOO-USERS group.

!viewGroups.png|thumbnail!

This is happening because when we query Microsoft AD for the list of members inside that group we expect a list of users that has the following structure:

{noformat:title=BAMBOO-ENGR}
# BAMBOO-ENGR, bamboo, atlassian.local
dn: CN=BAMBOO-ENGR,OU=bamboo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member: CN=bamboo.user0014,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member: CN=bamboo.user0013,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member: CN=bamboo.user0012,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member: CN=bamboo.user0011,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member: CN=bamboo.user0010,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
...
{noformat}

However, the results from querying the other group looks like this:

{noformat:title=BAMBOO-USERS}
# BAMBOO-USERS, bamboo, atlassian.local
dn: CN=BAMBOO-USERS,OU=bamboo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member;range=0-1499: CN=bamboo.user1413,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member;range=0-1499: CN=bamboo.user1412,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member;range=0-1499: CN=bamboo.user1411,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member;range=0-1499: CN=bamboo.user1410,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
member;range=0-1499: CN=bamboo.user1409,OU=users,OU=howTo,DC=atlassian,DC=local
...
{noformat}

All the results from the BAMBOO-USERS group have *member;range=0-1499:* – according to [Microsoft|https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Aa367017], by default, only the first 1.500 members of a group are accessible through LDAP via an attribute called *member;range=0-1499* even if the group contains more than 1.500 members.

Bamboo is not able to parse/handle that range parameter and it's reporting that the group has 0 users.

h3. Notes

You can test and check this using a very useful command called {{ldapsearch}}. If you want to know whether you're affected by this issue you can use your *atlassian-user.xml* file information to run the following command and look for the *range* attribute in the results:

{code}
ldapsearch -D "<securityPrincipal>" \
           -w "<securityCredential>" \
           -p <port> \
           -h <host> \
           -b "<baseContext>" \
           "<groupSearchFilter>" \
           member
{code}

You will find each one of the tags mentioned above inside your *atlassian-user.xml* file -- just replace the tags with the actual values so it looks similar to this:

{code}
ldapsearch -D "CN=administrator,CN=users,DC=atlassian,DC=local" \
           -w "password123" \
           -p 389 \
           -h atlassian.local \
           -b "DC=atlassian,DC=local" \
           "(&(objectCategory=group)(|(cn=BAMBOO-ENGR)(cn=BAMBOO-USERS)))" \
           member
{code}

h3.Workaround

There are no known workarounds at this time. However please keep in mind that this shouldn't affect users ability to access the application or even admins to grant and manage user access and such. This only affects the user count inside the *Groups* page.
fields.summary: Bamboo reporting 0 (zero) as user count for Microsoft Active Directory groups

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Fastlane Task throws a timeout error if there is no output for one minute.

h3. Environment
- Bamboo 6.3.2
- Any OS

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Fastlane Task and configure it as needed.
# Make the Task run without producing any output for more than one minute.

h3. Expected Results
Build continues to run normally.

h3. Actual Results
Build fails with error message
{noformat}
build	06-Feb-2018 14:23:09	[15:23:09]: /usr/bin/xcrun /path/to/fastlane/gym/lib/assets/wrap_xcodebuild/xcbuild-safe.sh -exportArchive -exportOptionsPlist '/path/to/file.plist' -archivePath /path/to/file.xcarchive -exportPath '/path/to/file'
simple	06-Feb-2018 14:24:10	Failing task since return code of [/path/to/file] was -1 while expected 0
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
- No errors in agent log.
- No errors in server log.

h3.Workaround
- Fastlane starts the timeout timer every time it stops receiving command output.
- Enabling DEBUG can force output, potentially preventing the timeout. This may be possible with --verbose or -v in the Lane field of the Task config.

Alternatively, you can use a *Command* task instead of the Fastlane task and supply the lane as an argument:
* [Custom command executable|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/custom-command-executable-289277045.html]
fields.summary: Fastlane Task throws a timeout error if there is no output for one minute.
Subversion repository with variable fail to be migrated to the new format

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Currently when a Plan has multiple source repositories only the first one is monitored for Plan Branches. This is currently a limitation -- only the primary repository is scanned for branches.

h3. Suggestion

It would be nice if Bamboo could monitor/scan branches across all source repositories associated to a Plan and not only the primary source repository.
fields.summary: Bamboo should monitor branches across all source repositories inside a Plan

fields.description: Customer would like to be able to store multiple versions of their product in a single repository, and use Bamboo to trigger a different plan based on which version branch sends the pull request. Our current functionality triggers the all build plans associated with the main branch which is being pulled into, as opposed to the branch which initiates the pull request. There is currently no known work around.
fields.summary: Source branch detection for pull request triggered builds.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
As for now, when a user creates a variable in Bamboo, it's only plain text.

h3. Accepted Solution
Parse content of variable and make it clickable if it's a link (for example, URL link).
fields.summary: Make variables clickable

Caused by: java.security.spec.InvalidKeySpecException: Could not generate secret key
  at javax.crypto.SecretKeyFactory.generateSecret(SecretKeyFactory.java:347)
  ... 74 more
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: password empty
  at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.symmetric.OpenSSLPBKDF$PBKDF.engineGenerateSecret(Unknown Source)
  at javax.crypto.SecretKeyFactory.generateSecret(SecretKeyFactory.java:336)
  ... 74 more{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
Show the full stacktrace in the Bamboo logs and a meaningful error when testing the connection through the UI.
It seems that error is not considered an error for Bamboo which is logging this error as an info restricting the stacktrace.
fields.summary: Missing SSH passphrase causes a misleading error: "Cannot decode connection params"

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, SSH Proxy timeout is hardcoded for a 120000 ms.  This sometimes makes it difficult to work with very large repositories, as they timeout before the checkout is complete.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add option to set SSH Proxy timeout configuration in {{setenv.sh}} 

h3. Workaround

none
fields.summary: Allow customization of SSH Proxy timeout configuration

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Depending on the number of build & deployment results, logs and artifacts the Expiry process may take hours or even days to finish. This is most common to large Bamboo instances with hundreds of thousands of build results, and the impact is amplified if you're *not* using _Complete build & deployment results, build & release artifacts and all logs_. This means that only artifacts and logs are getting removed, but all of your builds still exist in the database, and since Bamboo runs quite a few (rather complex) SQL queries to find what results must be removed, the more results you have, the more time Bamboo will take to execute the SQL queries in the background.

h3. Workaround

Please consider using the _Complete build & deployment results, build & release artifacts and all logs_ option inside the *Expiry* configuration to completely remove builds & deployments from the database as well and not only artifact and logs -- which are mostly used to free up disk space.
fields.summary: Improve performance of the Expiry process

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The current design of Bamboo will allow scripts to run and modify files from outside the working directory. This can cause problems since the filesystem can be modified depending on the user permissions (the user running the Bamboo server or the remote agent).

h3. Suggested Solution
Use docker as a building container. This would guarantee a restricted environment for the build tasks.

h3. Workaround
# Avoid using local agents. Any local agent will have the same permissions used by the Bamboo server user, so will be able to modify the server files
# Make sure you run your remote agents with a user with restricted permissions. That will restrict the access only to agent files/folders.
#* In Unix like instances you can use *chroot* to restrict the folders available for the user running the agent.
fields.summary: Bamboo builds should be restricted to their working directory

fields.description:
Problem: Customers who want to migrate  plans to specs configured have to export each plan manually thought the user interface. When users have large numbers of builds this means a lot of time consuming pointing and clicking to get what they need. 

 

Proposed Solution: Create a feature which will allow for globally exporting all plans as specs with the option of either yaml or java output.
fields.summary: Export all Bamboo plans as specs

fields.description: The plan configure branches resource in Atlassian Bamboo before version 6.2.3 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability through the name of a branch.
fields.summary: XSS in the plan configure branches resource through the name of a branch - CVE-2017-18082

fields.description: The signupUser resource in Atlassian Bamboo before version 6.3.1 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability through the value of the csrf token cookie.

fields.description: The update user administration resource in Atlassian Bamboo before version 6.3.1 allows remote attackers to modify user data including passwords via a Cross-site request forgery (CSRF) vulnerability.
fields.summary: Cross-site request forgery (CSRF) in the update user administration resource - CVE-2017-18042

fields.description: The viewDeploymentVersionJiraIssuesDialog resource in Atlassian Bamboo before version 6.2.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the name of a release.
fields.summary: XSS in the viewDeploymentVersionJiraIssuesDialog resource through the name of a release - CVE-2017-18041

fields.description: The viewDeploymentVersionCommits resource in Atlassian Bamboo before version 6.2.0 allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the name of a release.
fields.summary: XSS in the viewDeploymentVersionCommits resource through the name of a release - CVE-2017-18040

fields.description:
h3. Problem
In order to assign an agent to a Job through REST API we need the Project ID, but this information does not seem to be available through RESTs

h3. Solution
Add the Project ID to rest APIs returning Project details:
e.g. <URL>/rest/api/latest/search/projects, <URL>/rest/api/latest/project/{PROJ-KEY}
fields.summary: REST APIs for Projects should show the Project id

fields.description:
h3. Problem
In order to assign an agent to a Job through REST API we need the job ID, but this information does not seem to be available through RESTs

h3. Solution
Add the Job ID to rest APIs returning Job details:
e.g. <URL>/rest/api/latest/search/jobs/{PLAN-KEY}
fields.summary: REST APIs for Jobs should show the Job id

fields.description:
h6. Overview
The set of notifications offered for now only caters when *all* jobs are completed - [All Jobs Completed|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-notifications-for-a-plan-and-its-jobs-289276973.html#Configuringnotificationsforaplananditsjobs-JobEvents].

There will be occasions when users need to be notified when job(s) are started as well.

h6. Suggestion
* Have an additional option to configure notifications when job(s) are started
* If possible, provide a granular options for the following:
** single job
** multiple job
** all jobs
fields.summary: Notification for Job Started Event

fields.description:
h3. Summary
As for today, the AMIs configured for Bamboo use Maven version 3.2. 

h3. Accepted Solution
Upgrade AMIs to use Maven 3.5.2 (or latest).
fields.summary: Update maven in the current AMIs

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

There is not a way to add optional command line tags to the CodeDeploy task.  

For example:
{noformat:title=create-deployment flags}
--ignore-application-stop-failures
{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution

* Add check-boxes for optional CLI flags


h3. Workaround

Current workaround would be to build the CLI command by hand, and use the "Command" task.  This would require storing the AWS CLI keys unencrypted on the Agent machine, or on Bamboo server.
fields.summary: Add option for Command Line Tags in the AWS CodeDeploy Task

fields.description:
h3. Summary

There are users that cannot share/enter AWS Secret Access Key for security reasons, which is an impediment when it comes to using AWS.
h3. Accepted Solution

Have the possibility to create the EC2 configuration without the need of entering the AWS Secret Access Key.
fields.summary: Set EC2 configuration in Bamboo without the need of entering AWS Secret Access Key

fields.description: it's hard to choose correct release as several releases have the same long name part. It would be more convenient if release chooser shows full name of release without trimming. See screenshot
fields.summary: Make release selection control wider

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo import will fail with a foreign key constraint violation if there are any Project level permissions defined for Repository Stored Specs (RSS).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# {{Project Settings > Bamboo Specs repositories > Add a repository}}
# {{Bamboo Administration > Export}} (base export is fine, no results required)
# Take export and try to import it into a fresh Bamboo instance from the setup wizard

h3. Expected Results
Import succeeds

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2018-01-30 04:56:22,141 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [XmlMigrator] Reading file: /home/bamboo/rss_export.zip/db-export/projects.xml
2018-01-30 04:56:22,239 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [BatchingBatch] HHH000315: Exception executing batch [java.sql.BatchUpdateException: Batch entry 0 insert into RSS_PERMISSION_PROJECT (PROJECT_ID, REPOSITORY_ID, PERMISSION_ID) values (32800769, 32014340, 98305) was aborted: ERROR: insert or update on table "rss_permission_project" violates foreign key constraint "fk_sdkg2ib2cxckimq5dst51gmpg"
  Detail: Key (project_id)=(32800769) is not present in table "project".  Call getNextException to see other errors in the batch.], SQL: insert into RSS_PERMISSION_PROJECT (PROJECT_ID, REPOSITORY_ID, PERMISSION_ID) values (?, ?, ?)
2018-01-30 04:56:22,240 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23503
2018-01-30 04:56:22,240 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [SqlExceptionHelper] Batch entry 0 insert into RSS_PERMISSION_PROJECT (PROJECT_ID, REPOSITORY_ID, PERMISSION_ID) values (32800769, 32014340, 98305) was aborted: ERROR: insert or update on table "rss_permission_project" violates foreign key constraint "fk_sdkg2ib2cxckimq5dst51gmpg"
  Detail: Key (project_id)=(32800769) is not present in table "project".  Call getNextException to see other errors in the batch.
2018-01-30 04:56:22,240 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23503
2018-01-30 04:56:22,240 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [SqlExceptionHelper] ERROR: insert or update on table "rss_permission_project" violates foreign key constraint "fk_sdkg2ib2cxckimq5dst51gmpg"
  Detail: Key (project_id)=(32800769) is not present in table "project".
2018-01-30 04:56:22,244 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-1] [BambooStAXMappingHelperAbstractImpl] Exception during processing projects.project #7
javax.persistence.PersistenceException: org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute batch
	at org.hibernate.internal.ExceptionConverterImpl.convert(ExceptionConverterImpl.java:147)
	at org.hibernate.internal.ExceptionConverterImpl.convert(ExceptionConverterImpl.java:155)
	at org.hibernate.internal.ExceptionConverterImpl.convert(ExceptionConverterImpl.java:162)
{noformat}

h3.Workaround

h6. Option 1
Remove any RSS Permissions from the UI via *Project Settings > Bamboo Specs repositories* and perform the export + import procedure again. 

The below SQL query will assist in identifying any Projects in your Bamboo instance with explicit RSS permissions:
{code:sql}
SELECT DISTINCT PROJECT_KEY, TITLE 
FROM RSS_PERMISSION_PROJECT RSS
  JOIN PROJECT P ON RSS.PROJECT_ID = P.PROJECT_ID
{code}

h6. Option 2
Manually strip any {{<rssPermissions>}} elements and their content from the *db-export/projects.xml* file of the export. E.g remove anything like this:
{code}
<rssPermissions>
    <repository id="360451"/>
</rssPermissions>
{code}

Note: The import will work, however you will have no project level permissions for Bamboo Specs repositories. They will need to be re-created via the UI once the import completes.
fields.summary: Bamboo import fails when there are entries in RSS_PERMISSION_PROJECT

fields.description:
h3. Summary
XSRF Error when trying to clear system log errors

h3. Environment
Bamboo 6.3.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# With *Enable XSRF protection* checked in  *Security > Security Settings*
# In *System > System Errors*, right click the button "Clear all error logs" and *Copy Link*, then paste it to the browser address bar, enter.

h3. Expected Results
The errors are cleared as if you'd with clicking the button. 

h3. Actual Results
An exception is thrown
{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: XSRF Token Validation failed (XSRF_FAILURE_NO_TOKEN_IN_PARAMS).
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooXsrfTokenInterceptor.doIntercept(BambooXsrfTokenInterceptor.java:60)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.AbstractBambooInterceptor.intercept(AbstractBambooInterceptor.java:25)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:247)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.ParametersInterceptor.doIntercept(ParametersInterceptor.java:134)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.MethodFilterInterceptor.intercept(MethodFilterInterceptor.java:98)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:247)
	at org.apache.struts2.interceptor.FileUploadInterceptor.intercept(FileUploadInterceptor.java:246)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:247)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.ModelDrivenInterceptor.intercept(ModelDrivenInterceptor.java:99)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:247)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.ChainingInterceptor.intercept(ChainingInterceptor.java:157)
.......

fields.description:
It would be nice to have some sort of default permissions for Linked repositories in Bamboo, similar to what Fisheye & Crucible have, where you can manage default access permissions for all repositories:

!fisheye_default_repository_permissions.png|thumbnail!

This way administrators can decide which users, groups and roles should have default access to all Linked repositories created in Bamboo. For example, if you do not want to allow all logged-in users to have access across all Linked repositories, you could easily uncheck the *Grant read access to all logged in users* option, as opposed to the current behavior, where admins must immediately correct permissions after creating Linked repositories and must also review the creation of all Linked repositories to ensure the correct permissions have been set by other admins. There's no way to manage all this from one place.
fields.summary: Linked Repository Default Permissions

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo git commands when Git 2.16 is installed with fail with a "ssh variant 'simple' does not support setting port" error. Git version 2.16.0-rc0 does not work well with OpenSSH version 6.7 or older as stated in this bug report:
* https://bugs.chromium.org/p/git/issues/detail?id=7

h3. Environment
* Git 2.16 installed
* OpenSSH older than 6.8 (e.g. Ubuntu 14.04 LTS has 6.6)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Git 2.16
# Add a repository polling trigger to a plan with a git repository or run a build with a source code checkout task

h3. Expected Results
Git commands succeed

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command /usr/bin/git ls-remote ssh://ed2992ee-7805-434a-b2d6-8532e08d6cba@127.0.0.1:24938/PROJ/repo.git failed with code 128. Working directory was [/atlassian-bamboo-6.3.0/temp]., stderr:
fatal: ssh variant 'simple' does not support setting port
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:689)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.getRemoteRefs(GitCommandProcessor.java:478)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.lambda$getRemoteRefs$1(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:568)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.CallableResultCache$1.load(CallableResultCache.java:38)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.CallableResultCache$1.load(CallableResultCache.java:34)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$LoadingValueReference.loadFuture(LocalCache.java:3527)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.loadSync(LocalCache.java:2319)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.lockedGetOrLoad(LocalCache.java:2282)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.get(LocalCache.java:2197)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.get(LocalCache.java:3937)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.getOrLoad(LocalCache.java:3941)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$LocalLoadingCache.get(LocalCache.java:4824)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.collections.AlwaysInvalidatingCacheDecorator.get(AlwaysInvalidatingCacheDecorator.java:64)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.collections.AlwaysInvalidatingCacheDecorator.getUnchecked(AlwaysInvalidatingCacheDecorator.java:125)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.CallableResultCache.call(CallableResultCache.java:141)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.getRemoteRefs(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:576)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.resolveBranch(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:528)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.obtainLatestRevision(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:627)
{noformat}


h3.Workaround
* Downgrade Git to a version >= 1.8.1.5 and < 2.16
* If using Bamboo *6.3.1* specifically, you must use Git version >= 2.0 and < 2.16 due to [BAM\-19623: Old versions of git fail with error: Missing value for 'credential.helper' (fixed in Bamboo 6.3.2)|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-19623]
fields.summary: Git 2.16 commands failing with ssh variant 'simple' does not support setting port error in Bamboo (Git 2.16 compatibility)

fields.description: It would be nice to have the ability to disable repository configuration in Bamboo. Similar to what Fisheye & Crucible does where you can stop/start the repository. Bamboo uses a polling mechanism for branch/change detection, and it would be a good idea to have a switch where you can turn ON/OFF the repository whether it's a Linked repository or plan-level repository, so you can easily deactivate it instead of having to delete it if you want to temporarily prevent people from using that configuration, and also to ensure that none of Bamboo's background processes will run for that repository.
fields.summary: Add ability to disable/deactivate repository

fields.description: Bamboo has Plan-level repositories and Linked repositories. It would be nice to have some sort of Project-level repositories so that they're available to all Plans inside that Project and let Project admins manage repository permissions without going too deep into the Plan configuration and at the same time not have it available across the entire instance and across all Projects / Plans.
fields.summary: Add Project-level repository configuration

fields.description: If user doesn't have Create repository permission but has Create global permission he can create plan. On plan create wizard he can't choose option to skip repository selection and forced to use one of the existing linked repository.
fields.summary: User without Create repository permission can't create plan without repository

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Promote existing release to an environment showing the list of release which include expired release
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a build plan PROJ-PLAN
 # Configure shared artifact in the above plan
 # Run the plan, ex PROJ-PLAN-1
 # Create and deploy a release for the above build result, ex. release-1
 # Repeat Step 3-4 twice to have PROJ-PLAN-2, PROJ-PLAN-3, release-2 and release-3
 # Select "Complete build & deployment results, build & release artifacts and all logs" in Global Expiry
 # Run the expiry twice
 The Deployment Project Releases list showing "Incomplete" for "release-1"
 # Click on "Deploy" button
 # Select the option "Promote existing release to this environment"
 # Check the list of Releases

h3. Expected Results

"release-1" will not be shown in the list
h3. Actual Results
 * "release-1" is showing in the list
 * Using it will have error due to the release has expired

h3. Notes

Expired or Incomplete release should not be shown in the list or it should be labelled with "Incomplete" or "Expired"
fields.summary: Expired Release listed in Promote Existing Release list

fields.description:

Bamboo will show the related deployment projects

h3. Actual Results
!related deployment.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Anonymous user couldn't view related deployment project

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After the implementation of [BAM-11544|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-11544], Bamboo is able to branch from multiple repositories, but the automatic branch merging features ("Branch Updater" and Gatekeeper") only work for the default repository.

h3. Accepted Solution
Extend the feature to all repositories in the plan.
fields.summary: Implement automatic branch merging functionality for non-default repositories

fields.description:
h3. Summary

As for today, bamboo.cfg.xml saves the database credentials in plain text and there is no alternative to it. 

Additionally affected are:
* <BAMBOO_INSTALL>/conf/server.xml if using a different Keystore Password for SSL
* <BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/configuration/crowd.properties, if using an external Crowd.
* <BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/configuration/atlassian-user.xml prior to 6.6.x Embedded Crowd
* <BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/configuration/administration.xml AWS credentials for Elastic agents

h3. Suggested Solution
Have a way to hide or encrypt credentials.

h3. Why this is important
Security reasons.
fields.summary: Mask/Encrypt credentials in configuration files
Number of build log lines to show is displayed with a decimal point

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Artifacts are not visible to users for release if permissions no explicitly set in plan

h3. Environment
Bamboo 6.3.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan that has an artifact as result.
# Create a deployment project that uses this plan.
# Create a group (let's call it "bamboo-user") and a user that belongs to this group (let's call it "User1").
# For the build plan's Project, define "Plan permissions inheritance" to the group bamboo-user to View and Build.
# For the deployment project, allow the group bamboo-user to View and Edit.

h3. Expected Results
User1 is able to create a release with this plan.

h3. Actual Results
User is not able to create release since they can't see the artifact in the "Create New Release" screen:
 !Screen Shot 2018-01-23 at 17.59.24.png|thumbnail!  

h3. Notes
User1 is able to see and download the artifact from the build result.

h3. Workaround
Explicitly set plan permissions to the group bamboo-user to View and Build.
fields.summary: Artifacts are not visible to users for release if permissions no explicitly set in plan

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, there is no option to let Bamboo send a notification to only the user that created the respective Branch, as Bamboo doesn't record the user who created the branch.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add an option like *User that created the branch* in the *Plan configuration -> Notifications -> Recipient type* section.

h3. Why this is important
 This is to avoid unnecessary notifications being sent to all the committers who did a commit in the branch.

h3. Workaround 
Add a script task at the end of the plan that runs git log against the respective branch and find the user who created the branch and trigger an email to just that user via command prompt.
fields.summary: Send notification to only the user that created a branch

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
By default, AWS CodeDeploy deployment fails if files already exist in a deployment target location but weren't part of the previous successful deployment.

The AWS CodeDeploy SDK allows this behavior to be overridden by supplying a different value for the [FileExistsBehavior|https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/services/codedeploy/model/FileExistsBehavior.html], however currently the Bamboo CodeDeploy task does not support this.

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement a configuration item in the AWS CodeDeploy task that allows the user to specify the FileExistsBehavior.
 
h3. Workaround 
* Script task with AWS CLI use: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/deploy/create-deployment.html using the {{--file-exists-behavior OVERWRITE}} argument.
fields.summary: Support changing the File Exists Behavior for AWS CodeDeploy deployments in Bamboo

fields.description: It would be great if Agent Matrix results can be retrieved through REST API call
fields.summary: REST call for Agent Matrix

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the only way to configure Elastic Bamboo authentication is to use an AWS Access Key and Secret Key combination. 

Some organizations may prefer an alternate authentication method for Elastic Bamboo, such as being able to assume an IAM role that is assigned to the server hosting Bamboo.

h3. Suggested Solution
* Implement alternative authentication modes for Elastic Bamboo, specifically the ability to assume an IAM role from the environment.
 
h3. Workaround 
None
fields.summary: Ability to assume an IAM role assigned to the server Bamboo is on for Elastic Bamboo access

fields.description: RIght now credentials for Docker Pull/Push tasks are stored in plain text in DB. They should be encrypted to prevent stealing sensitive data or corrupt DockerHub or local registry.
fields.summary: Encode Docker credentials

fields.description:
h3. Summary

 When you select {{Agent-Local}} artifact handler it creates a single copy of the artifact on the remote agent, but the link generated to download the artifact does not work as the agent does not have a web service to serve the artifact. This results in a {{Page Unavailable}} error when trying to access the link displayed in the {{Artifacts}} tab of the build results, and customers thinking the artifact generation failed.

 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Select {{Agent-Local}} artifact handler in Bamboo configuration UI.
# Run build.
# Attempt to access link generated and displayed on the {{Artifacts}} page of the build results. 

h3. Expected Results
The link generated and displayed should be valid and accessible, or state the agent the artifact is available on, and the path of the artifact on that agent.

h3. Actual Results
The {{Artifacts}} page on the build results displays a download link to an invalid URL. 

h3. Workaround
None
fields.summary: Artifact Handlers generate invalid download link
When Shared credential is used for SSH/SCP task Bamboo doesn't warn when credential is removed

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When Bamboo is connected to Jira/Crowd for user management, Bamboo synchronizes users that have been marked as {{INACTIVE}} in Jira/Crowd.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect Bamboo to Jira/Crowd for external user management. See notes on [integrating Bamboo with Crowd|http://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/docs-0602/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Crowd#IntegratingBamboowithCrowd-Notes] to learn more.
# Mark a couple users as inactive inside Jira/Crowd.
# Go back to Bamboo and click 'Synchronise now' from the *Bamboo administration > Overview > Security > User repositories* page.
# Access the *Bamboo administration > Overview > Security > Users* page.

h3. Expected Results

Inactive users are not showing up in the list of users anymore.

h3. Actual Results

Inactive users have been flagged as {{INACTIVE}}.

h3. Notes

This might be a problem due to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-19621.
fields.summary: Prevent inactive users synchronization when connected to Jira/Crowd

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo doesn't hide inactive users from the list of users when adding permissions to a plan, project and etc. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to the *Bamboo administration > Overview > Security > Users* page.
# Flag a user as {{INACTIVE}}.
# Access the *Bamboo administration > Overview > Secutiry > Global permissions* page.
# Start typing the user's name inside the 'Add users' field under *User access*.

h3. Expected Results

No results. Bamboo should display a message saying "No matches found".

h3. Actual Results

It's possible to select the {{INACTIVE}} user and grant permissions.

h3. Notes

{panel:title=Important|borderStyle=dashed|titleBGColor=#F7D6C1|bgColor=#FFFFCE}
This does NOT mean inactive users will be able to access Bamboo. Inactive users cannot access/log in to the application while flagged as {{INACTIVE}}.
{panel}
fields.summary: Inactive users are showing up in the list when adding permissions

fields.description:
Bamboo currently does not support a diverging configuration between master and feature branches. This means the master branch configuration is always the same as the feature branch configuration. 

Users should have the ability to define a diverging configuration for their feature branches.

h3.Workaround
Use this add-on [Conditional tasks for Bamboo|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1219706/conditional-tasks-for-bamboo]
fields.summary: Bamboo should support divergent plan branches

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Bamboo stores SSH Access Keys against Bitbucket repositories simply with the URL of the Bamboo instance. It's difficult to tell in Bitbucket which SSH Access Keys are currently in use by Bamboo and by which Plan / Repository.

h3. Suggested Solution
Label the Access Keys with a more descriptive format. E.g:
* _Plan Level Repositories:_ Bamboo URL - Plan - Repository Name
* _Linked Repositories:_ Bamboo URL - Linked Repository Name
fields.summary: Label SSH Access Keys in Bitbucket with the Plan and Repository Name

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently Bamboo will store an SSH Access Key in Bitbucket whenever a repository is created. If that repository is deleted and re-created, it will add another access key. Over time, this can build up and make the list of Access Keys in Bitbucket difficult to manage and it's hard to know which keys are still in use by Bamboo.

h3. Suggested Solution
Delete the SSH Access Key from Bitbucket upon removal of the repository in Bamboo. 

h3. Workaround 
N/A
fields.summary: Bamboo should cleanup SSH Access Keys in Bitbucket when the repository is removed

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Atlassian Marketplace plugin files are not available in a repository.
h3. Suggested Solution
Allow files to be pulled from a repository.
h4. Why this is important 
Dependencies such as jar files needs to be manually found and downloaded from the Marketplace.
fields.summary: Make Marketplace Plugins / integrations files available a public repository

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently once a plan is managed via RSS, by design there's no path back to a standard plan and it can no longer be edited through the UI.

h3. Suggested Solution
UI action that allows a plan to be transitioned back to a standard plan, the action would need to warn the user that RSS will be disabled for the repository that created this plan as well as warn of any other plans that RSS for that repository manages (if they exist).

h3. Workarounds
h4. Publish Specs for a specific plan manually.
When Specs are published to Bamboo server manually (see [our tutorial|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/tutorial-create-a-simple-plan-with-bamboo-java-specs-894743911.html#Tutorial:CreateasimpleplanwithBambooJavaSpecs-Step5:PublishBambooSpecstotheBambooserver] for more details) then plan will be disconnected from RSS and it will be possible to edit its configuration from UI.
h4. Clone plan
The RSS managed plan needs to be cloned. However, this will lose all the build history.
h4. Run SQL query
(!) This is not a recommended way to proceed and you need to make sure you take a database backup before applying this solution.
* stop Bamboo
* take DB backup
* run the following queries
{code}
-- disconnect Bamboo plan from RSS
UPDATE build
SET vcs_specs_source_id=NULL
WHERE full_key='<full_build_plan_key>'
AND build_type='CHAIN';

-- disconnect Bamboo deployment from RSS
UPDATE deployment_project
SET vcs_specs_source_id=NULL
WHERE plan_key='<full_deployment_plan_key>';
{code}
* start Bamboo
fields.summary: Ability to transition a plan from Repository Stored Specs (RSS) managed back to a standard plan

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, if we use the "Artifacts Download Task" then the created date of the artifacts are modified with the new date when the artifacts are downloaded by the "Artifacts Download Task". There can be scenarios where the customer wants to preserve the date of the artifacts to identify the libraries or for any other reasons.

h3. Suggested Solution
We should have an option in the artifacts creation task to ask the user to archive the artifacts once created and an option in the artifacts download task to extract the artifact once downloaded. This way the creation date will be preserved.

h3. Workaround
Use the script task to archive the artifatcs created and then to unarchive the downloaded task.
fields.summary: Preserve Artifacts creation date

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When the Bamboo Continuous Plugin Deployment app is included in a Bamboo Specs plan, the created Deployment Environment will fail.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a deployment environment configuration including Continuous Plugin Deployment task
# Run it from Bamboo UI - that will work
# Export deployment project to Java Specs
# Run code without modification using mvn -Ppublish-specs
# Run deployment project from the UI again

h3. Expected Results
Deployment is successful

h3. Actual Results
Deployment fails, with the following in the Deployment log
{noformat}
simple 11-Jan-2018 11:25:48 Starting task 'Deploy ...' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.deploy.continuous-plugin-deployment:deploy-task'
simple 11-Jan-2018 11:25:48	Unable to find the artifact with id <id> in this task's context. Has an artifact subscription been configured for that artifact in this job?
simple 11-Jan-2018 11:25:48	Finished task 'Deploy ...' with result: Failed
{noformat} 
The context string used, {{"v2:<id>:2:0:<name>"}} is incremented to {{"v2:<id>:4:0:<name>"}} when run.
fields.summary: Bamboo Continuous Deployment Plugin context breaks when using Specs

fields.description:
Hi,

Creating this for a vendor:

{quote}

At the moment its possible to generate one java spec out of a deployment project including multiple environments.

It would be nice to have the same for build projects.
Now I have to go plan by plan.

{quote}

 

Cheers,

Anne Calantog
fields.summary: Generate Java Specs for all plans in a project

fields.description:
Starting with Bamboo 6.2, Bamboo adds the project menu, which exposes a list of all projects, including projects the user has no access to.

This is a cause for concern in multi-tenant setups where users should not see projects they don't have access to because it would potentially expose confidential information, such as the names of other customers or their projects.

From a usability perspective it's also questionable why a user would be displayed the list of all projects if they don't have access to them - this seems to have little value to the user

h3. Workaround
# Navigate to {{Administration >> Add-ons >> Manage apps}}
# Select "All apps" to list all the apps
# Click on {{System apps >> Atlassian Bamboo Web Resources Plugin >> 98 of 98 modules enabled}}
# Disable either *page-projects* or *feature-projects-table* module
This will make the All Project list to be empty
# Click on {{Bamboo Global Header >> 39 of 39 modules enabled}}
# Disable *Projects (project)* module
This will make Project menu disappear
fields.summary: As an Administrator I do not want Bamboo to expose the list of all projects to all users

fields.description: Update the bamboo Windows and Linux AMI ( specifically with a version of the linux kernel) with operating system updates that contains fixes for CVE-2017-5754.
fields.summary: Update the bamboo AMIs that contains fixes for CVE-2017-5754

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, there is not a permission definition to allow users to view the configuration of a build plan while disallowing edit permissions.

h3. Suggested Solution

Create a new permission definition between the Plan View, and Plan Edit permissions which allow viewing the configuration, without being able to make changes.
 
h3. Workaround

Admin exports plan to specs, and creates a new 'non-live' plan to allow others to view the configuration.
fields.summary: Create permission definition to allow viewing of plan configuration without edit capability
